   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:23.0/42.0/2.2, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:226/13/0.07, ALT / AST:51/65, Alk Phos / T Bili:108/0.5,
   Lactic Acid:1.3 mmol/L, Albumin:2.8 g/dL, LDH:359 IU/L, Ca++:7.8 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.6 mg/dL, PO4:4.5 mg/dL
   ECHO
   The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall thicknesses
   are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 20-30 %)
   secondary to extensive akinesis involving the apex and anterior septum;
   there is severe hypkinesis of the anterior free wall, inferior septum,
   and inferior free wall. The basal half of the posterior and lateral
   walls contracts normally. Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased
   left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). Right ventricular
   chamber size is normal. with depressed free wall contractility. The
   aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. A bileaflet aortic
   valve prosthesis is present. The aortic valve prosthesis appears well
   seated, with normal leaflet/disc motion and transvalvular gradients.
   Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are
   mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to
   acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation may be
   significantly UNDERestimated.] The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly
   thickened. There is no pericardial effusion.
   Impression: extensive anteroseptal-apical myocardial infarct of unknown
   acuity; inferior hypokinesis; findings consistent with multivessel
   obstructive coronary [**Last Name (un) **] disease
   Assessment and Plan
   This is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac
   arrest.
   # Asystolic arrest:  Etiology includes respiratory arrest leading to
   cardiac arrest, especially since had been complaining of dyspnea prior
   to presentation. Nevertheless no evidence of hypoxia on initial
   presentation. Alternatively, the evidence of systolic failure and
   hypokinetic areas in LV may represent a recent ischemic event (but no q
   waves on ECG).  Most likely is a combination of these two. Less likely
   tamponade, acidosis, PE.
   - needed pressor support overnight, with effective weaning.
   - cte ventilation, decrease FiO2 as able
   - try to ween propofol to better assess brain/seizure activity and f/u
   neuro recs today
   # Afib: paroxysmal in nature, remained rate controlled overnight. Not
   on any medications at this time.
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin for AVR and
   PTT 60-90.
   # ARF: Cr up to 2.1 from 1.0 in [**Month (only) 25**]. Overnight with decreased u/o.
   Most likely decreased forward flow in the setting of poor EF. No
   evidence of crackles on exam or LE edema, but exam is limited. If blood
   pressure normalizes then may try furosemide to improve forward flow and
   increase renal perfusion. Ionotropic support was briefly necessary.
   Alternative etiology is decreased volume but PCWP is elevated on ECHO.
   BUN/Cre is too high to suggest intrinsic renal cause such as ATN, but
   given his HypoTN this is a possibility.
   # Possible Cardiogenic shock: Has edema and uop now down to almost zero
   - BPs stable and appearts fluid overloaded on exam so will try lasix
   today to increase uop (bolus X 1) follow UOP today
   #
twitching
 movements noted with weaning sedation: concern for
   seizure, but no coordinated movements were noted. His neuro exam was
   unchanged, i.e. fixed/dialated pupils, no doll
s eye.  EEG was
   recording so it should provide clear information. Resolved with
   restarting of sedation. Propofol was chosen for its shorter
 life in
   case need to wean again.
   - F/u neurology recs and wean down propofol prior to their exam to
   allow them to assess seizures.
   # Anemia: HCT this am at 27 down from 31 on admission. VS stable. Will
   monitor, if continues to decrease may need scan for bleeding.
   # DM2: hold PO hypoglycemics
   - insulin sliding scale
   # FEN: NPO overnight
   # ACCESS: L femoral line, may need to be d/c
d as placed in the ED but
   will reassess for PIVs prior to d/c
ing.. Add PiVs for more access.
   # PROPHYLAXIS: heparin ggt
   # CODE: Full. Had long discussion with daughters regarding [**Name2 (NI) **]
   prognosis. They are actively consulting their rabbi [**First Name (Titles) 1986**] [**Last Name (Titles) 6677**] of
   care. Family may not want to increase care but may not be comfortable
   withdrawing care.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2108-2-28**] 03:00 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2108-2-28**] 03:00 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2108-2-28**] 05:52 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:
   ------ Protected Section ------
   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I have also reviewed the notes of Dr(s). [**Name (NI) 6668**].
   I would add the following remarks:
   Above discussed extensively with patient. Above discussed extensively
   with family member, next of [**Doctor First Name 372**] or health care proxy. Above discussed
   with primary care physician: [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **]. [**Last Name (STitle) 6684**]. I have discussed this plan
   with Dr(s). CCU taem.
   Total time spent on patient care: 40 minutes of critical care time.
   Additional comments:
   Doing poorly, with seizures off sedation by EEG, few reflexes.
   Plan:
   1. Neurology consult for seizure meds
   2. Diuresis given CXR findings, oliguria
   3. Continue close contact with the family - poor prognosis explained to
   them today
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 3494**], MD
   on:[**2108-2-29**] 11:19 ------

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2 (DM2), peripheral artery disease (PAD), and a recent cardiac arrest. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with multiple medical conditions.

The patient's recent events include:

* Hypothermia, which was treated with fluids and warming measures
* Cardiac arrest, which was likely caused by respiratory arrest and systolic failure
* Electrolyte imbalance, which was treated with correction of potassium, calcium, and magnesium levels
* Coagulopathy, which was treated with fresh frozen plasma and vitamin K
* Acute kidney injury (AKI), which is likely caused by decreased forward flow and elevated left ventricular filling pressure
* Cardiogenic shock, which is characterized by hypotension, oliguria, and edema

The patient's current medications include:

* Heparin for atrial fibrillation and prophylaxis
* Propofol for sedation and seizure prophylaxis
* Insulin sliding scale for glycemic control
* Lasix for diuresis

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels
* Low hemoglobin and hematocrit levels
* Elevated troponin-T levels
* Abnormal liver function tests (LFTs)

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Extensive anteroseptal-apical myocardial infarct on echocardiogram
* Mild mitral regurgitation and aortic regurgitation on echocardiogram

The patient's clinical condition is complicated by:

* Seizure activity, which is being treated with propofol and anticonvulsant medication
* Cardiogenic shock, which is being treated with diuresis and vasopressor support
* AKI, which is being treated with fluid management and hemodynamic support
* Coagulopathy, which is being treated with correction of electrolyte imbalances and anticoagulant therapy

The patient's prognosis is poor, and the family is actively consulting with a rabbi regarding their options for end-of-life care. The patient's code status is full code, and the family is being counseled regarding the potential for further interventions.

Based on this information, potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Further cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest
* Worsening of cardiogenic shock or AKI
* Development of sepsis or multi-organ failure
* Bleeding complications due to coagulopathy
* Worsening of seizure activity or development of status epilepticus
* Development of respiratory failure or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

Summary:

The patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2 and peripheral artery disease who presented with asystolic cardiac arrest. He was resuscitated and intubated. His initial assessment revealed a profound coagulopathy, likely caused by a combination of warfarin and antibiotic use. He was treated with vitamin K, fresh frozen plasma, and heparin. His cardiac function is compromised, with an ejection fraction of 20% and elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. He is on norepinephrine for blood pressure support and mechanical ventilation for respiratory support.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding complications due to coagulopathy: The patient's INR is 2.2, which is still elevated, and he is at risk for bleeding complications, particularly if his coagulopathy is not adequately managed.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is at risk for further kidney damage due to his underlying medical conditions and potential for hypovolemia.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a history of antibiotic use, and his white blood cell count is elevated, which may indicate an underlying infection.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he is at risk for further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's neurologic exam is concerning, with fixed pupils and no corneal reflexes, which may indicate a severe neurological injury.
6. Respiratory complications: The patient is on mechanical ventilation, and he is at risk for respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia or respiratory failure.
7. Infection: The patient's immune system is compromised, and he is at risk for infection, particularly with the use of antibiotics and other medications.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of diabetes and peripheral artery disease, which may increase his risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea or constipation.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's coagulopathy and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
2. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management and medication dosing accordingly.
3. Consider further evaluation for underlying infections, such as blood cultures or imaging studies.
4. Continue to optimize the patient's cardiac function, including adjusting his medication regimen and monitoring his cardiac rhythm.
5. Consider further evaluation of the patient's neurological status, including imaging studies or electrophysiological testing.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary.
7. Consider prophylactic antibiotics for the patient's respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.
8. Monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust his insulin regimen as necessary to prevent hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.

   ECHO
   The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall thicknesses
   are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 20-30 %)
   secondary to extensive akinesis involving the apex and anterior septum;
   there is severe hypkinesis of the anterior free wall, inferior septum,
   and inferior free wall. The basal half of the posterior and lateral
   walls contracts normally. Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased
   left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). Right ventricular
   chamber size is normal. with depressed free wall contractility. The
   aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. A bileaflet aortic
   valve prosthesis is present. The aortic valve prosthesis appears well
   seated, with normal leaflet/disc motion and transvalvular gradients.
   Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are
   mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to
   acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation may be
   significantly UNDERestimated.] The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly
   thickened. There is no pericardial effusion.
   Impression: extensive anteroseptal-apical myocardial infarct of unknown
   acuity; inferior hypokinesis; findings consistent with multivessel
   obstructive coronary [**Last Name (un) **] disease
   Assessment and Plan
   [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac arrest.
   .
   # Asystolic arrest:  Etiology includes respiratory arrest leading to
   cardiac arrest, especially since had been complaining of dyspnea prior
   to presentation. Nevertheless no evidence of hypoxia on initial
   presentation. Alternatively, the evidence of systolic failure and
   hypokinetic areas in LV may represent a recent ischemic event (but no q
   waves on ECG).  Most likely is a combination of these two. Less likely
   tamponade, acidosis, PE.
   - needed pressor support overnight, with effective weaning.
   .
   # Afib: paroxysmal in nature, remained rate controlled overnight. Not
   on any medications at this time.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin for AVR and
   PTT 60-90.
   .
   # ARF: Cr up to 2.1 from 1.0 in [**Month (only) 25**]. Overnight with decreased u/o.
   Most likely decreased forward flow in the setting of poor EF. No
   evidence of crackles on exam or LE edema, but exam is limited. If blood
   pressure normalizes then may try furosemide to improve forward flow and
   increase renal perfusion. Ionotropic support may be necessary.
   Alternative etiology is decreased volume but PCWP is elevated on ECHO.
   BUN/Cre is too high to suggest intrinsic renal cause such as ATN, but
   given his HypoTN this is a possibility.
   - sediment and u/lytes
   .
   #
twitching
 movements noted with weaning sedation: concern for
   seizure, but no coordinated movements were noted. His neuro exam was
   unchanged, i.e. fixed/dialated pupils, no doll
s eye.  EEG was
   recording so it should provide clear information. Resolved with
   restarting of sedation. Propofol was chosen for its shorter
 life in
   case need to wean again.
   .

   [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac arrest.
   .
   # Asystolic arrest:  Etiology includes respiratory arrest leading to
   cardiac arrest, especially since had been complaining of dyspnea prior
   to presentation. Nevertheless no evidence of hypoxia on initial
   presentation. Alternatively, the evidence of systolic failure and
   hypokinetic areas in LV may represent a recent ischemic event (but no q
   waves on ECG).  Most likely is a combination of these two. Less likely
   tamponade, acidosis, PE.
   - needed pressor support overnight, with effective weaning.
   .

   on any medications at this time.
   .
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin for AVR and
   PTT 60-90.
   .
   # ARF: Cr up to 2.1 from 1.0 in [**Month (only) 25**]. Overnight with decreased u/o.
   Most likely decreased forward flow in the setting of poor EF. No
   evidence of crackles on exam or LE edema, but exam is limited. If blood
   pressure normalizes then may try furosemide to improve forward flow and
   increase renal perfusion. Ionotropic support may be necessary.
   Alternative etiology is decreased volume but PCWP is elevated on ECHO.
   BUN/Cre is too high to suggest intrinsic renal cause such as ATN, but
   given his HypoTN this is a possibility.
   - sediment and u/lytes
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 90-year-old man with diabetes mellitus type 2, peripheral artery disease, and a history of cardiac arrest. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with a diagnosis of hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acute kidney injury. He received FFP and vitamin K, and his international normalized ratio (INR) improved from 22 to 2.2. He was also started on heparin and propofol for sedation. His cardiac status is complicated, with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 20%, and evidence of extensive anteroseptal-apical myocardial infarct and multivessel obstructive coronary disease. He has a bileaflet aortic valve prosthesis and mild mitral regurgitation.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Continued cardiac failure and hypotension
	* Increased risk of arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation
	* Potential for further myocardial infarction or worsening of existing damage
2. Renal complications:
	* Continued acute kidney injury and potential for further deterioration
	* Increased risk of chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease
3. Coagulopathy:
	* Risk of bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage
	* Potential for further coagulopathy if heparin is discontinued
4. Respiratory complications:
	* Risk of respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation
	* Potential for pneumonia or other respiratory infections
5. Neurological complications:
	* Risk of seizure activity or status epilepticus
	* Potential for further neurological deterioration, including stroke or encephalopathy
6. Infection:
	* Risk of sepsis or septic shock
	* Potential for further infection, including pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or bloodstream infection
7. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Risk of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation
	* Potential for further gastrointestinal complications, including nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea
8. Hemodynamic instability:
	* Risk of hypotension or hypertension
	* Potential for further hemodynamic instability, including cardiac arrest or cardiogenic shock

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Cardiovascular Status:**

* The patient has extensive anteroseptal-apical myocardial infarct of unknown acuity, with inferior hypokinesis and multivessel obstructive coronary disease.
* Left ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 20-30 %) with extensive akinesis involving the apex and anterior septum.
* The patient has a bileaflet aortic valve prosthesis with trace aortic regurgitation and mild (1+) mitral regurgitation.
* The patient is at risk for cardiogenic shock due to poor left ventricular function and elevated left ventricular filling pressure.

**Coagulopathy:**

* The patient has a coagulopathy likely caused by a combination of warfarin and antibiotic use, which has resolved with fresh frozen plasma and vitamin K.
* The patient is currently on heparin for atrioventricular valve replacement and prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 60-90 seconds.

**Renal Status:**

* The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL from 1.0 mg/dL on admission.
* The patient's blood pressure is stable, but urine output is decreased, and he has edema, which may indicate cardiogenic shock or decreased forward flow.
* The patient's BUN/Cr ratio is too high to suggest intrinsic renal cause such as acute tubular necrosis, but given his hypotension, this is a possibility.

**Neurological Status:**

* The patient has fixed and dilated pupils, no doll's eye reflex, and no coordinated movements were noted, which raises concern for seizure activity.
* The patient's EEG was recorded, and the results are pending.

**Other Complications:**

* The patient has anemia with a hematocrit level of 27% down from 31% on admission.
* The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus and is at risk for hypoglycemia.
* The patient has a femoral line, which may need to be discontinued and replaced with peripheral intravenous lines (PiVs) for more access.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Cardiogenic shock due to poor left ventricular function and elevated left ventricular filling pressure.
* Seizure activity due to the patient's neurological status.
* Renal failure due to acute kidney injury or decreased forward flow.
* Hypotension due to cardiogenic shock or coagulopathy.
* Infection due to stress ulcer or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to immobility and coagulopathy.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust therapy as needed.
* Wean the patient off propofol and assess seizure activity.
* Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust therapy as needed.
* Consider adding PiVs for more access and discontinuing the femoral line.
* Continue to monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust therapy as needed.
* Consider holding PO hypoglycemics and starting insulin sliding scale.

   This is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac

   evidence of crackles on exam or LE edema, but exam is limited. If blood
   pressure normalizes then may try furosemide to improve forward flow and
   increase renal perfusion. Ionotropic support may be necessary.
   Alternative etiology is decreased volume but PCWP is elevated on ECHO.
   BUN/Cre is too high to suggest intrinsic renal cause such as ATN, but
   given his HypoTN this is a possibility.
   - sediment and u/lytes

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, an elderly man with DM2 and PAD, presented with asystolic cardiac arrest. He was intubated and received pressor support overnight, with effective weaning. He developed hypothermia, which was treated with FFP and vitamin K. His coagulopathy was resolved with FFP and vitamin K, and he is now on heparin for AVR and PTT 60-90.

The patient's cardiac condition is characterized by extensive anteroseptal-apical myocardial infarct of unknown acuity, inferior hypokinesis, and findings consistent with multivessel obstructive coronary disease. His ECHO showed a severely depressed left ventricular systolic function with an LVEF of 20-30%. He also has a bileaflet aortic valve prosthesis with trace aortic regurgitation and mild (1+) mitral regurgitation.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a HCT of 27, down from 31 on admission. His glucose levels are stable, and he is on insulin sliding scale. His electrolyte levels are normal, except for a slightly elevated BUN/Cr ratio.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a pH of 7.4, pCO2 of 39, and SpO2 of 100%. He is on ventilator support with a tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate of 16, and PEEP of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's neurological status is stable, with fixed and dilated pupils, no doll's eye reflex, and no evidence of seizure activity. His EEG was recorded and is pending.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Sepsis: The patient has been on antibiotics for an unknown duration, and his WBC count is elevated.
2. ARF: The patient's Cr level is elevated, and he has decreased urine output.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of AFib and is at risk for further cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Bleeding: The patient has a coagulopathy and is at risk for bleeding.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient is on ventilator support and is at risk for respiratory failure.
6. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of seizures and is at risk for further neurological complications.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Pressor support as needed.
2. Heparin for AVR and PTT 60-90.
3. Insulin sliding scale for glycemic control.
4. Monitoring of electrolyte levels and acid-base status.
5. Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status and neurological function.
6. Consideration of further diagnostic tests, such as an echocardiogram or cardiac catheterization, to evaluate the patient's cardiac condition.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2 (DM2) and peripheral artery disease (PAD) who presented with asystolic cardiac arrest. He was intubated and mechanically ventilated, and received fluid resuscitation, pressor support, and antibiotics.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of coagulopathy, with an international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.2 and a partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 42.0 seconds. He was treated with fresh frozen plasma (FFP) and vitamin K, and is now on heparin for atrial fibrillation (AFib) and aortic valve replacement (AVR).

The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 106 mg/dL. He has decreased urine output and is at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI).

The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows evidence of extensive anteroseptal-apical myocardial infarction (MI) with inferior hypokinesis, and a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 20-30%. He has a bileaflet aortic valve prosthesis and mild mitral regurgitation.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a tidal volume (TV) of 550 mL and a respiratory rate (RR) of 16 breaths per minute. He is receiving oxygen therapy via an endotracheal tube.

The patient's neurologic status is stable, with fixed and dilated pupils and no doll's eye movement. He has no evidence of seizure activity, but did have twitching movements noted with weaning of sedation.

The patient's medication list includes:

* Heparin sodium
* Propofol
* Insulin sliding scale
* Furosemide (if blood pressure normalizes)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to decreased urine output and elevated BUN and creatinine levels
* Cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or worsening of cardiac function
* Respiratory complications such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, or worsening of oxygenation
* Neurologic complications such as seizures, increased intracranial pressure, or worsening of neurologic status
* Infection complications such as sepsis, urinary tract infection, or pneumonia
* Bleeding complications due to coagulopathy and heparin therapy

The patient's care plan includes:

* Continuing pressor support and monitoring of blood pressure
* Monitoring of renal function and urine output
* Continuing antibiotic therapy and monitoring for signs of infection
* Continuing cardiac monitoring and management of cardiac function
* Monitoring of respiratory status and oxygenation
* Monitoring of neurologic status and seizure activity
* Continuing heparin therapy and monitoring for bleeding complications

   This is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac
   arrest.
   # Asystolic arrest:  Etiology includes respiratory arrest leading to
   cardiac arrest, especially since had been complaining of dyspnea and
   chocking sensation prior to presentation. Alternatively, the evidence
   of systolic failure and hypokinetic areas in LV may represent a recent
   ischemic event (but no q waves on ECG).  Most likely is a combination
   of respiratory arrest in setting of CHF.
   - BP continues to be stable w/o pressors
   - continue ventilation, decrease FiO2 as able
   - Will continue to attempt to diurese (-1Lt) however patient has had
   decreased UOP, but responded to lasix yesterday.
   - Multidisciplinary meeting
   # Seizure activity: EEG c/w generalized periodic epileptiform
   activity.  Per Neurology these indicate severe brain anoxia and are
   associated with poor outcomes (>90% mortality or severe neurologic
   disability).
   - Will continue Levitiracetam per Neurology and continue to wean off
   propophol.
   - Continue EEG.
   # Afib: paroxysmal in nature, remained rate controlled overnight. Not
   on any medications at this time.
   # ARF: Cr up to 2.1 from 1.0 in [**Month (only) 25**]. Most likely related to CHF.
   Urine output improved with furosemide. Will continue to diurese (-1Lt).
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin ggt for AVR
   and PTT 60-90.
   # Anemia: HCT stable at 26. VS stable. Will continue to monitor.
   # Hypoglycemia: Unclear etiology. Possibilities include poor
   elimination of insulin in the setting of ARF or poor GNG in the setting
   of arrest. Also possible is hypoxic brain injury affecting the
   pituitary.
   - Will continue D50 infusions and D5 KVO.
   # DM2: hold PO hypoglycemics
   - insulin sliding scale
   # FEN: NPO overnight
   # ACCESS: L femoral line, may need to be d/c
d as placed in the ED but

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, with a need for mechanical ventilation and a high risk of respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of asystolic cardiac arrest and is at risk for further cardiac arrests due to his underlying cardiac conditions.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate level suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, indicating potential renal failure, which could lead to electrolyte imbalances and acid-base disturbances.
5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, indicating anemia, which could lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient's glucose level is low, indicating hypoglycemia, which could lead to seizures, confusion, and even death if not treated promptly.
7. Coagulopathy: The patient's international normalized ratio (INR) is elevated, indicating coagulopathy, which could lead to bleeding complications.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's EEG shows generalized periodic epileptiform activity, which could indicate severe brain anoxia and poor outcomes.
9. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate level suggest the possibility of infection, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
10. Multi-organ failure: The patient's underlying conditions and complications could lead to multi-organ failure, which would be a poor prognosis.

Based on this information, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of DM2, PAD, and CHF, who presented with asystolic cardiac arrest. He has been admitted to the ICU for ongoing management.

Key findings and concerns:

1. Respiratory support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 40% and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O. His SpO2 is 99%, and his ABG results indicate a pH of 7.48, PaO2 of 36, and PaCO2 of 120.
2. Cardiovascular status: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which is paroxysmal in nature and remains rate-controlled. His BP is stable, but his Cr is elevated at 2.3.
3. Neurological status: The patient has generalized periodic epileptiform activity on EEG, indicating severe brain anoxia and poor outcomes. He is receiving Keppra and propofol, and his sedation is being weaned.
4. Renal function: The patient has acute renal failure (ARF), with a Cr of 2.3. His urine output has improved with furosemide, but he is still producing less than 1 L of urine per day.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, likely related to warfarin and antibiotic use. He has received FFP and VitK, and is now on heparin for AVR and PTT 60-90.
6. Anemia: The patient's HCT is stable at 26, and his VS are stable.
7. Hypoglycemia: The patient has had two episodes of hypoglycemia, with a glucose level of 15 at 1 am. He is receiving D50 infusions and D5 KVO.
8. DM2: The patient's DM2 is being managed with insulin sliding scale and holding PO hypoglycemics.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated Cr and decreased urine output suggest possible sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he may be at risk for respiratory failure if his FiO2 is decreased or if he experiences further respiratory compromise.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's atrial fibrillation and elevated Cr suggest possible cardiac arrest, which could lead to further cardiovascular complications.
4. Neurological decline: The patient's generalized periodic epileptiform activity on EEG indicates severe brain anoxia and poor outcomes, which could lead to further neurological decline.
5. Renal failure: The patient's ARF is likely to continue, and he may require further interventions to improve his renal function.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy could lead to further bleeding complications, particularly if he experiences further trauma or surgical procedures.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia could lead to further cardiovascular complications, particularly if his HCT falls below 20.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for a range of medical complications, including sepsis, respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, neurological decline, renal failure, coagulopathy, and anemia. His ongoing management requires close monitoring and intervention to address these potential complications and improve his overall prognosis.

9. Multi-organ dysfunction: The patient has multi-organ dysfunction, including respiratory, cardiac, renal, and hepatic dysfunction. The patient's prognosis is poor, and the patient may be at risk for further organ dysfunction.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an elderly man with a complex medical history, including DM2, PAD, and CHF. He presented with asystolic cardiac arrest and has been in the ICU for several days.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 135/56 mmHg, heart rate of 99 bpm, and respiratory rate of 19 inspirations per minute. His oxygen saturation is 99% on a ventilator with a FiO2 of 40%. He has a history of atrial fibrillation, which is currently rate-controlled.

The patient has a significant neurological component, with a history of seizure activity and an EEG that suggests severe brain anoxia. He is currently receiving anticonvulsant therapy and will continue to be monitored for seizure activity.

The patient's renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 2.3 mg/dL. He has been receiving diuretic therapy and has shown some improvement in urine output.

The patient's blood glucose levels have been fluctuating, with a range of 40-84 mg/dL. He is receiving D50 infusions and D5 KVO to maintain euglycemia.

The patient has a coagulopathy, which is likely related to warfarin and antibiotic use. He has received FFP and vitamin K, and his PTT is currently within the normal range.

The patient's anemia is likely related to his underlying medical conditions, and his hemoglobin level is stable at 26.6 g/dL.

The patient's code status is full code, and his family is actively consulting with a rabbi regarding his prognosis and end-of-life care.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is receiving antibiotics, which may increase his risk of developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, which may be complicated by respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of asystolic cardiac arrest and may be at risk for further cardiac arrests.
4. Neurological deterioration: The patient has a history of seizure activity and may be at risk for further neurological deterioration.
5. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and he may be at risk for further renal failure.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels have been fluctuating, and he may be at risk for further hypoglycemic episodes.
7. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, which may increase his risk of bleeding complications.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, which may increase his risk of cardiovascular complications.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory values, and clinical status to identify any potential complications early and intervene promptly to prevent adverse outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a history of atrial fibrillation (AF), cardiac arrest, coma, and impaired skin integrity. They were started on Keppra for brain activity and received a loading dose of 1500mg followed by 500mg every 8 hours. The patient had a run of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) and was given IV lasix to improve urine output, which increased to 30cc/hr. However, creatinine (Cr) levels increased to 2.3. Blood glucose levels decreased to 60's during the afternoon and 15 at 1am, requiring two amps of D50. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 99bpm, and blood pressure of 135/56mmHg. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy, mechanical ventilation, and has an arterial line and multi-lumen line in place.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and current atrial fibrillation (AF) increases the risk of cardiac arrest.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine (Cr) levels have increased to 2.3, indicating potential kidney damage.
3. Hypoglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels have decreased to 15, requiring urgent treatment to prevent further complications.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, with mechanical ventilation in place. Weaning from the ventilator may be challenging.
5. Skin integrity issues: The patient's impaired skin integrity increases the risk of skin breakdown and infection.
6. DVT prophylaxis: The patient is at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to immobility and should receive prophylactic anticoagulation.
7. Stress ulcer prophylaxis: The patient's critical illness and mechanical ventilation increase the risk of stress ulcers, requiring prophylactic medication.
8. VAP prophylaxis: The patient's endotracheal tube increases the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), requiring prophylactic antibiotics and proper tube care.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor blood glucose levels closely and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
2. Continue Keppra therapy as prescribed.
3. Monitor creatinine levels and adjust diuretic therapy as needed.
4. Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor respiratory status closely.
5. Implement DVT prophylaxis and stress ulcer prophylaxis as prescribed.
6. Monitor for signs of skin breakdown and infection.
7. Consider weaning from the ventilator when clinically stable.
8. Continue to monitor for signs of cardiac arrest and atrial fibrillation.

   This is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac
   arrest.
   # Asystolic arrest:  Etiology includes respiratory arrest leading to
   cardiac arrest, especially since had been complaining of dyspnea prior
   to presentation. Nevertheless no evidence of hypoxia on initial
   presentation. Alternatively, the evidence of systolic failure and
   hypokinetic areas in LV may represent a recent ischemic event (but no q
   waves on ECG).  Most likely is a combination of these two. Less likely
   tamponade, acidosis, PE.
   - needed pressor support overnight, with effective weaning.
   - cte ventilation, decrease FiO2 as able
   - try to ween propofol to better assess brain/seizure activity and f/u
   neuro recs today
   # Afib: paroxysmal in nature, remained rate controlled overnight. Not
   on any medications at this time.
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin for AVR and
   PTT 60-90.
   # ARF: Cr up to 2.1 from 1.0 in [**Month (only) 25**]. Overnight with decreased u/o.
   Most likely decreased forward flow in the setting of poor EF. No
   evidence of crackles on exam or LE edema, but exam is limited. If blood
   pressure normalizes then may try furosemide to improve forward flow and
   increase renal perfusion. Ionotropic support was briefly necessary.
   Alternative etiology is decreased volume but PCWP is elevated on ECHO.
   BUN/Cre is too high to suggest intrinsic renal cause such as ATN, but
   given his HypoTN this is a possibility.
   # Possible Cardiogenic shock: Has edema and uop now down to almost zero
   - BPs stable and appearts fluid overloaded on exam so will try lasix
   today to increase uop (bolus X 1) follow UOP today
   #
twitching

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be determined:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of diabetes, peripheral artery disease, and recent cardiac arrest. He was found in asystolic cardiac arrest and was resuscitated. He has been in the ICU for several days, requiring pressor support, mechanical ventilation, and sedation. He has developed atrial fibrillation, which is rate-controlled, and has a coagulopathy likely due to warfarin and antibiotic use. He has acute kidney injury, which is suspected to be due to decreased forward flow in the setting of poor left ventricular function. He also has anemia, which is being monitored.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Complications:**
	* Cardiogenic shock due to poor left ventricular function and decreased forward flow.
	* Arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation, which may progress to ventricular fibrillation or tachycardia.
	* Myocardial infarction or ischemia due to decreased coronary perfusion.
2. **Renal Complications:**
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to decreased forward flow and poor left ventricular function, which may progress to chronic kidney disease.
	* Fluid overload due to increased capillary permeability and decreased renal function.
3. **Neurological Complications:**
	* Seizures due to possible hypoglycemia, electrolyte imbalances, or medication side effects.
	* Neurological damage due to prolonged hypoperfusion or hypoxia.
4. **Coagulation Complications:**
	* Bleeding due to coagulopathy and potential platelet dysfunction.
	* Thrombosis or deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to decreased mobility and anticoagulation therapy.
5. **Infectious Complications:**
	* Sepsis or septic shock due to underlying infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections.
	* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation.
6. **Gastrointestinal Complications:**
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulceration or coagulopathy.
	* Nutritional deficiencies due to decreased oral intake and possible malabsorption.

Overall, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, including cardiac, renal, neurological, coagulation, infectious, and gastrointestinal complications. Close monitoring and management are essential to prevent or minimize these complications and improve the patient's outcome.

   This is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac
   arrest.
   # Asystolic arrest:  Etiology includes respiratory arrest leading to
   cardiac arrest, especially since had been complaining of dyspnea and
   chocking sensation prior to presentation. Alternatively, the evidence
   of systolic failure and hypokinetic areas in LV may represent a recent
   ischemic event (but no q waves on ECG).  Most likely is a combination
   of respiratory arrest in setting of CHF.
   - back on pressors
   - Full code per family
   - AC with no spontaneous BR despite being off sedation.
   # Seizure activity: EEG c/w generalized periodic epileptiform
   activity.  Per Neurology these indicate severe brain anoxia and are
   associated with poor outcomes (>90% mortality or severe neurologic
   disability).
   - Will continue Levitiracetam and ativan.
   - Continue EEG monitoring.
   # Afib: RVR overnight after levo started. Down titrated levo. Responded
   to metoprolol IV x1.
   - continue to monitor
   # ARF: Cr stable. Most likely related to CHF. Will monitor U/O in the
   setting of pressor support. Careful diuresis as needed.
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin ggt for AVR
   and PTT 60-90.
   # Anemia: HCT stable. VS stable. Will continue to monitor.
   # Hypoglycemia: Unclear etiology. Possibilities include poor
   elimination of insulin in the setting of ARF or poor GNG in the setting
   of arrest. Also very likely is hypoxic brain injury affecting the
   pituitary.
   - Will continue D50 infusions and D5 KVO.
   # DM2: hold PO hypoglycemics
   - insulin sliding scale

   Nutrition:  start tube feeds today

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information is summarized:

* The patient is an elderly man with DM2 and PAD who presented with asystolic cardiac arrest.
* He has been experiencing respiratory arrest, which led to cardiac arrest, and may also have had a recent ischemic event.
* He has been treated with pressors and has been intubated.
* He has had seizures, which are indicative of severe brain anoxia and are associated with poor outcomes.
* He has developed atrial fibrillation (AF) and has been treated with metoprolol.
* He has acute kidney injury (ARF) and is being monitored for urine output.
* He has a coagulopathy, which has been treated with FFP and vitamin K.
* He has anemia, which is being monitored.
* He has had hypoglycemia, which may be due to poor elimination of insulin, poor glucose metabolism, or hypoxic brain injury.
* He has a complicated urinary tract infection (UTI) and has been treated with ceftriaxone.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is already compromised, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure.
* Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac status is already compromised, and further deterioration could lead to cardiac failure.
* Seizure activity: The patient has already had seizures, and further seizure activity could lead to poor outcomes.
* Infection: The patient has a complicated UTI, and further infection could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy could lead to bleeding complications.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia could lead to further compromise of his respiratory and cardiac status.
* Hypoglycemia: The patient's hypoglycemia could lead to further compromise of his neurological and cardiovascular status.
* ARF: The patient's ARF could lead to further compromise of his renal function and overall health.
* DVT: The patient is at risk for developing DVT due to his immobility and the presence of central lines.
* Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk for developing stress ulcer due to his critical illness and the presence of central lines.
* VAP: The patient is at risk for developing VAP due to his intubation and the presence of central lines.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the progress note, the patient is an elderly man with a history of DM2, PAD, and CHF who presented with asystolic cardiac arrest. He was intubated and started on pressors, including norepinephrine, to support his blood pressure. He also developed atrial fibrillation, which responded to metoprolol IV.

The patient's urine output trended down to 15 mL/hr after lasix, but improved with another dose of lasix. However, his blood pressure trended down into the 70s, and he was restarted on levophed to support his blood pressure.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a Hct of 24.7%. His WBC count is 11.5, and his platelet count is 253. His creatinine is 2.2 mg/dL, and his glucose is 76 mg/dL.

The patient's EEG showed generalized periodic epileptiform activity, indicating severe brain anoxia and associated with poor outcomes.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Asystolic cardiac arrest: likely related to respiratory arrest and CHF.
2. Seizure activity: generalized periodic epileptiform activity on EEG, indicating severe brain anoxia and poor outcomes.
3. Atrial fibrillation: responded to metoprolol IV.
4. Acute kidney injury (ARF): likely related to CHF and pressor support.
5. Coagulopathy: likely related to warfarin and antibiotic use, resolved with FFP/VitK.
6. Anemia: Hct stable, VS stable.
7. Hypoglycemia: unclear etiology, possibly related to poor elimination of insulin or poor GNG.
8. Complicated UTI: treated with ceftriaxone.
9. Respiratory failure: intubated and on ventilator support.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening of cardiac function: continued pressor support may worsen cardiac function.
2. Increased risk of bleeding: coagulopathy and pressor support may increase the risk of bleeding.
3. Further respiratory compromise: continued respiratory failure may worsen respiratory function.
4. Increased risk of infection: complicated UTI and pressor support may increase the risk of infection.
5. Further neurologic compromise: continued seizure activity and hypoglycemia may worsen neurologic function.
6. Increased risk of kidney injury: continued ARF may worsen kidney function.
7. Further metabolic complications: hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia may worsen metabolic function.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of DM2, PAD, and CHF who presented with asystolic cardiac arrest. He has been admitted to the ICU and has undergone various interventions, including pressor support, antibiotics, and anticoagulation therapy.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a Vt of 500 mL and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O. His SpO2 is 96%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has atrial fibrillation, and his blood pressure is 110/44 mmHg. He is receiving pressor support with norepinephrine and has a heart rate of 102 bpm.
* Neurological status: The patient has been experiencing seizures, and an EEG has confirmed generalized periodic epileptiform activity. He is receiving anticonvulsant therapy with leviracetam and ativan.
* Renal status: The patient has acute kidney injury, and his creatinine level is 2.2 mg/dL. He is receiving diuretic therapy with furosemide.
* Hematological status: The patient has a coagulopathy, likely related to warfarin and antibiotic use. He has been treated with FFP and vitamin K.
* Endocrine status: The patient has DM2 and is receiving insulin sliding scale therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require further interventions to improve his oxygenation and ventilation.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and he may require further adjustments to his pressor support therapy.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's seizures may indicate severe brain anoxia, which can lead to poor outcomes.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to further complications.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
* Infection: The patient's antibiotic therapy may not be adequate, leading to the development of a new infection.

The patient's family is actively involved in his care and has discussed his prognosis with his rabbi. They may not want to increase his care but may not be comfortable withdrawing care. The patient's code status is full code, and his family has expressed a desire for eventual tracheostomy and peg feeding if he is unable to be weaned off the ventilator within 7-10 days.

   This is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac
   arrest.
   # Asystolic arrest:  Etiology includes respiratory arrest leading to
   cardiac arrest, especially since had been complaining of dyspnea and
   chocking sensation prior to presentation. Alternatively, the evidence
   of systolic failure and hypokinetic areas in LV may represent a recent
   ischemic event (but no q waves on ECG).  Most likely is a combination
   of respiratory arrest in setting of CHF.
   - BP continues to be stable w/o pressors
   - continue ventilation, decrease FiO2 as able
   - Will continue to attempt to diurese (-1Lt) however patient has had
   decreased UOP, but responded to lasix yesterday.
   - Multidisciplinary meeting
   # Seizure activity: EEG c/w generalized periodic epileptiform
   activity.  Per Neurology these indicate severe brain anoxia and are
   associated with poor outcomes (>90% mortality or severe neurologic
   disability).
   - Will continue Levitiracetam per Neurology and continue to wean off
   propophol.
   - Continue EEG.
   # Afib: paroxysmal in nature, remained rate controlled overnight. Not
   on any medications at this time.
   # ARF: Cr up to 2.1 from 1.0 in [**Month (only) 25**]. Most likely related to CHF.
   Urine output improved with furosemide. Will continue to diurese (-1Lt).
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin ggt for AVR
   and PTT 60-90.
   # Anemia: HCT stable at 26. VS stable. Will continue to monitor.
   # Hypoglycemia: Unclear etiology. Possibilities include poor
   elimination of insulin in the setting of ARF or poor GNG in the setting
   of arrest. Also possible is hypoxic brain injury affecting the
   pituitary.
   - Will continue D50 infusions and D5 KVO.
   # DM2: hold PO hypoglycemics
   - insulin sliding scale
   # FEN: NPO overnight
   # ACCESS: L femoral line, may need to be d/c

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac
   arrest.
   # Asystolic arrest:  Etiology includes respiratory arrest leading to
   cardiac arrest, especially since had been complaining of dyspnea and
   chocking sensation prior to presentation. Alternatively, the evidence
   of systolic failure and hypokinetic areas in LV may represent a recent
   ischemic event (but no q waves on ECG).  Most likely is a combination
   of respiratory arrest in setting of CHF.
   - back on pressors, on norepi today
   - Full code per family
   - AC with no spontaneous BR despite being off sedation.
   # Seizure activity: EEG c/w generalized periodic epileptiform
   activity.  Per Neurology these indicate severe brain anoxia and are
   associated with poor outcomes (>90% mortality or severe neurologic
   disability).
   - Will continue Levitiracetam and ativan.
   - Continue EEG monitoring.
   # Afib: RVR overnight after levo started. Down titrated levo. Responded
   to metoprolol IV x1.
   - continue to monitor
   # ARF: Cr stable. Most likely related to CHF. Will monitor U/O in the
   setting of pressor support. Careful diuresis as needed.
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin ggt for AVR
   and PTT 60-90.
   # Anemia: HCT stable. VS stable. Will continue to monitor.
   # Hypoglycemia: Unclear etiology. Possibilities include poor
   elimination of insulin in the setting of ARF or poor GNG in the setting
   of arrest. Also very likely is hypoxic brain injury affecting the
   pituitary.
   - Will continue D50 infusions and D5 KVO.
   # DM2: hold PO hypoglycemics
   - insulin sliding scale
   # Complicated UTI: Ceftriaxone x 10 days
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  start tube feeds today
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2108-2-28**] 03:00 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2108-2-28**] 03:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  heparin gtt
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 90-year-old man with diabetes mellitus type 2, peripheral arterial disease, and a history of cardiac arrest. He was admitted to the ICU with asystolic cardiac arrest and has been receiving pressor support. He has developed atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury. He has also had seizures and is at risk for further neurological damage. His electrolyte levels are abnormal, and he has a coagulopathy. He has been treated with antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and blood pressure medications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and acute kidney injury may lead to further cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory Complications: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory distress or failure.
3. Neurological Complications: The patient's seizures and risk of further neurological damage may lead to permanent brain damage or death.
4. Coagulopathy Complications: The patient's coagulopathy may lead to bleeding complications, such as hemorrhage or hematuria.
5. Infection Complications: The patient's complicated urinary tract infection may lead to sepsis or septic shock.
6. Hypoglycemia Complications: The patient's hypoglycemia may lead to further neurological damage or death if not treated promptly.
7. Anemia Complications: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further complications, such as heart failure or respiratory distress.
8. Diabetic Complications: The patient's diabetes mellitus type 2 may lead to further complications, such as ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic coma.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment. The plan is to continue pressor support, antibiotics, and anticonvulsants. The patient's electrolyte levels will be closely monitored, and his coagulopathy will be managed with blood products and heparin. The patient's hypoglycemia will be treated with D50 infusions and D5 KVO. The patient's anemia will be monitored, and his diabetes mellitus type 2 will be managed with insulin sliding scale. The patient's complicated urinary tract infection will be treated with antibiotics, and his respiratory failure will be managed with mechanical ventilation. The patient's atrial fibrillation will be managed with anticoagulation therapy and rate control medications.

The patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of DM2, PAD, and CHF who presented with asystolic cardiac arrest. He has been in the ICU for several days and has had multiple complications, including hypoglycemia, seizures, atrial fibrillation, acute kidney injury, and coagulopathy. He is currently on pressors, ventilator support, and IV fluids. His family has requested full code status and is considering tracheostomy and peg tube placement if he is unable to be weaned off the ventilator in 7-10 days.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is dependent on the ventilator. He may be at risk for further respiratory deterioration, including respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which may lead to further cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
3. Renal failure: The patient has acute kidney injury, which may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.
4. Neurological complications: The patient has had seizures and may be at risk for further neurological complications, such as stroke or brain death.
5. Infection: The patient has a complicated UTI, which may lead to sepsis or septic shock.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, which may lead to bleeding complications.
7. Hypoglycemia: The patient has had hypoglycemia and may be at risk for further episodes.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has CHF, which may lead to further cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
9. Metabolic complications: The patient has DM2, which may lead to further metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia or ketoacidosis.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications and requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these complications.

   This is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac
   arrest.
   # Asystolic arrest:  Most likely respiratory arrest.
   - Not requiring pressors

   - AC with no spontaneous BR despite being off sedation.
   - Trach/Peg next week
   # Seizure activity: Per Neurology these indicate severe brain anoxia
   and are associated with poor outcomes (>90% mortality or severe
   neurologic disability).
   - Will continue Levitiracetam.
   - Continue EEG monitoring.

   - continue to monitor

   pressors. Cre mildly elevated vs admission.
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin ggt for AVR
   and PTT 60-90.
   # Anemia: HCT stable. VS stable. Will continue to monitor.
   # Hypoglycemia: Improving with TF
   - Will continue D50 infusions as needed.
   # DM2: hold PO hypoglycemics
   - insulin sliding scale
   # Complicated UTI: Ceftriaxone x 10 days

He has atrial fibrillation with a heart rate less than 100 beats per minute and is receiving heparin infusion. His laboratory results show anemia, coagulopathy, and acute kidney injury, but his creatinine levels are stable. He has a complicated urinary tract infection and is being treated with ceftriaxone for 10 days. His neurological status is unchanged, and he is being monitored for seizure activity.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is slightly elevated, and his plateau pressure is 17 cmH2O, which may indicate respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a complicated urinary tract infection and is receiving antibiotics, which may increase his risk of sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels are stable, but his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are elevated, which may indicate acute kidney injury.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy likely caused by warfarin and antibiotic use, which may increase his risk of bleeding.
5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin levels are low, which may indicate anemia and increase his risk of bleeding.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient's glucose levels are low, which may indicate hypoglycemia and increase his risk of neurologic damage.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure is slightly elevated, which may indicate cardiovascular instability and increase his risk of cardiac arrest.
8. Neurological deterioration: The patient's neurological status is unchanged, and he is at risk of further deterioration due to his age and underlying medical conditions.

Summary:

The patient is a 90+ year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, peripheral artery disease, and atrial fibrillation who presented with asystolic cardiac arrest. He was intubated and placed on pressors. His current vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 89 bpm, blood pressure of 101/43 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He has a history of seizure activity, atrial fibrillation, acute kidney injury, coagulopathy, anemia, hypoglycemia, and complicated urinary tract infection. He is receiving various medications, including heparin, antibiotics, and insulin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is dependent on mechanical ventilation. Prolonged mechanical ventilation can lead to respiratory failure, and the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia is high.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of complicated urinary tract infection and is receiving antibiotics. Sepsis can occur due to the infection, and the patient's immune system may be compromised.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation and may be at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient has a history of seizure activity and may be at risk for further neurological complications such as brain herniation, cerebral edema, and seizures.
5. Bleeding Complications: The patient has a coagulopathy and is receiving anticoagulant therapy. Bleeding complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding, intracranial bleeding, and hematuria are possible.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of complicated urinary tract infection and is at risk for further infections such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, central line-associated bloodstream infection, and catheter-associated urinary tract infection.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient is receiving antibiotics and may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as Clostridioides difficile infection, antibiotic-associated diarrhea, and gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Endocrine Complications: The patient has diabetes mellitus type 2 and is at risk for endocrine complications such as hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, and adrenal insufficiency.
9. Renal Complications: The patient has acute kidney injury and is at risk for further renal complications such as chronic kidney disease, end-stage renal disease, and electrolyte imbalances.
10. Nutritional Complications: The patient is malnourished and may be at risk for nutritional complications such as protein-calorie malnutrition, electrolyte imbalances, and impaired wound healing.

Summary:

The patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, peripheral artery disease, and atrial fibrillation, who presented with asystolic cardiac arrest. He remains intubated and on pressors. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 89 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 101/43 mmHg. His respiratory support includes a ventilator with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

* Respiratory failure, with a respiratory system compliance of 157 and a plateau pressure of 17 cmH2O
* Cardiac arrest, with a heart rate of 89 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 101/43 mmHg
* Coagulopathy, with a partial thromboplastin time of 130 seconds and an international normalized ratio of 3.2
* Anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 8.3 g/dL
* Hypoglycemia, with a blood glucose level of 58 mg/dL
* Complicated urinary tract infection, with a diagnosis of asystolic cardiac arrest

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.9 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 267 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL
* Glucose: 58 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 359 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.5 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 4.9 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Coagulopathy
* Anemia
* Hypoglycemia
* Complicated urinary tract infection
* Sepsis
* Multi-organ dysfunction syndrome
* Neurologic impairment
* End-stage renal disease

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued pressor support
* Full code status
* Antibiotic therapy for complicated urinary tract infection
* Monitoring for coagulopathy and anemia
* Management of hypoglycemia with D50 infusions and D5 KVO
* Insulin sliding scale for diabetes mellitus type 2
* Prophylactic measures for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a [**Age over 90 **] yo man with DM2, PAD presents with asystolic cardiac
   arrest.
   # Asystolic arrest:  Etiology includes respiratory arrest leading to
   cardiac arrest, especially since had been complaining of dyspnea and
   chocking sensation prior to presentation. Alternatively, the evidence
   of systolic failure and hypokinetic areas in LV may represent a recent
   ischemic event (but no q waves on ECG).  Most likely is a combination
   of respiratory arrest in setting of CHF.
   - back on pressors, on norepi today
   - Full code per family
   - AC with no spontaneous BR despite being off sedation.
   # Seizure activity: EEG c/w generalized periodic epileptiform
   activity.  Per Neurology these indicate severe brain anoxia and are
   associated with poor outcomes (>90% mortality or severe neurologic
   disability).
   - Will continue Levitiracetam and ativan.
   - Continue EEG monitoring.
   # Afib: RVR overnight after levo started. Down titrated levo. Responded
   to metoprolol IV x1.
   - continue to monitor
   # ARF: Cr stable. Most likely related to CHF. Will monitor U/O in the
   setting of pressor support. Careful diuresis as needed.
   # Coagulopathy: Likely [**1-2**] combination of warfarin and antibiotic use.
   No evidence of DIC. Resolved with FFP/VitK. Now on heparin ggt for AVR
   and PTT 60-90.
   # Anemia: HCT stable. VS stable. Will continue to monitor.
   # Hypoglycemia: Unclear etiology. Possibilities include poor
   elimination of insulin in the setting of ARF or poor GNG in the setting
   of arrest. Also very likely is hypoxic brain injury affecting the
   pituitary.
   - Will continue D50 infusions and D5 KVO.
   # DM2: hold PO hypoglycemics
   - insulin sliding scale
   # Complicated UTI: Ceftriaxone x 10 days
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an elderly man who presented with asystolic cardiac arrest, likely due to a combination of respiratory arrest and systolic failure. He has a history of DM2, PAD, and is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 89 bpm, and blood pressure of 101/43 mmHg. He is receiving pressors, including norepinephrine, and is being monitored for fluid balance and electrolyte levels.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Atrial fibrillation, which was treated with metoprolol and is being monitored.
2. Acute kidney injury, which is likely related to cardiac failure and is being managed with careful diuresis.
3. Coagulopathy, which was treated with FFP and VitK, and is now being managed with heparin.
4. Anemia, which is stable and being monitored.
5. Hypoglycemia, which is unclear in etiology and is being managed with D50 infusions and D5 KVO.
6. Complicated urinary tract infection, which is being treated with ceftriaxone.
7. Seizure activity, which is being managed with leviracetam and ativan, and is being monitored with EEG.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.9 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 267 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL
* Glucose: 58 mg/dL
* Calcium: 7.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.5 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.9 mg/dL

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing pressor support and monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results.
* Managing his cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac failure.
* Monitoring for and managing complications such as respiratory failure, sepsis, and bleeding.
* Continuing his antibiotic therapy and monitoring for signs of infection.
* Managing his electrolyte levels and acid-base balance.
* Monitoring his neurological status and managing any further seizure activity.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of DM2, PAD, and asystolic cardiac arrest. He is currently in the ICU, intubated, and on mechanical ventilation. The patient has severe ulcers on his right foot, consistent with prior documentation by vascular surgery, and is at risk for infection.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.2°F, heart rate of 85 bpm, and blood pressure of 124/50 mmHg. His respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute and an SpO2 of 100%. His cardiac status is complicated by atrial fibrillation, and he has a history of CHF.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 10.9 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.3 g/dL, and platelet count of 267 K/uL. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 25 mEq/L, and his creatinine is 2.8 mg/dL. His electrolyte levels are normal, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's medical conditions include DM2, PAD, CHF, and atrial fibrillation. He has a history of seizures and is currently being treated with leviracetam. He also has a coagulopathy, which is likely related to warfarin and antibiotic use, and is being treated with heparin.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Infection: The patient has severe ulcers on his right foot, which are at risk for infection. He is also at risk for developing a complicated UTI.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, which increases his risk of developing respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of CHF and atrial fibrillation, which increases his risk of developing cardiac complications.
4. Seizures: The patient has a history of seizures and is currently being treated with leviracetam. He is at risk for developing further seizures.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, which increases his risk of bleeding.
6. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, which increases his risk of developing further anemia.
7. Hypoglycemia: The patient has a history of hypoglycemia, which increases his risk of developing further hypoglycemia.
8. DM2: The patient has a history of DM2, which increases his risk of developing further complications.

In conclusion, the patient is a 90-year-old man with a complex medical history and multiple medical conditions. He is at risk for developing various medical complications, including infection, respiratory failure, cardiac complications, seizures, coagulopathy, anemia, hypoglycemia, and DM2. He requires close monitoring and management of his medical conditions to prevent and treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, peripheral artery disease, and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) following asystolic cardiac arrest. He has a severe anoxic brain injury, atrial fibrillation, acute kidney injury, and coagulopathy. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a plateau pressure of 16 cmH2O and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O. His blood glucose levels are unstable, and he has a history of hypoglycemia. He is also receiving antibiotics for a complicated urinary tract infection.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's complicated urinary tract infection and coagulopathy increase his risk of developing sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) increase his risk of developing respiratory failure, which could lead to prolonged mechanical ventilation and increased risk of complications.
3. Neurological damage: The patient's severe anoxic brain injury and atrial fibrillation increase his risk of developing neurological damage, including seizures, stroke, and cognitive impairment.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation and history of asystolic cardiac arrest increase his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and history of anticoagulant use increase his risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hemorrhagic shock and death.
6. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease increase his risk of developing renal failure, which could lead to end-stage renal disease and increased risk of complications.
7. Infection: The patient's complicated urinary tract infection and coagulopathy increase his risk of developing other infections, including pneumonia, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.

Overall, the patient is at high risk of developing multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.
